overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students learn the meaning of a correlation coefficient, <math><mi>r</mi></math>, and a coefficient of determination, <math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. They create scatter plots and use technology to determine a linear regression equation and <math><msup><mi>r</mi></msup></math>. Students interpret the results to determine whether a line is an appropriate model for a data set. They learn that a correlation is a necessary, but not sufficient, condition for causation.

overview_item_data_items: I can choose a level of accuracy appropriate when reporting quantities.
I can fit a linear function to a data set with a linear association and use it to solve problems.
I can use technology to determine the correlation coefficient of a linear regression equation for a data set.
I can differentiate between causation and correlation.
A correlation is a measure of how well a regression model fits a data set.
The correlation coefficient is a numeric summary of bivariate data that measures the strength of the relationship between two variables.
The <math><mi>r</mi></math>-value falls between (-1) and 0 when the data show a negative association or between 0 and 1 when the data show a positive association.
The closer the correlation coefficient is to 1 or (-1), the stronger the relationship is between the two variables.
Causation is when one event causes a second event. A correlation is a necessary, but not sufficient, condition for causation.
When some other reason may cause the same result or when there are other unknown or unobserved variables, correlation is often mistaken for causation.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students describe the association between independent and dependent variables.
Students learn the meaning and range of the correlation coefficient, <math><mi>r</mi></math>.
Students determine whether a line of best fit is appropriate for a data set.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_title: Using the Correlation Coefficient to Assess a Line of Best Fit
overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students determine a line of best fit and calculate <math><mi>r</mi></math> and <math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> for a data set.
Students learn that correlation is a necessary, but not sufficient, condition for causation.
Students consider how a common response and confounding variable are mistaken for causation.
